comments.content:
Here are the clarifications for each statement:

Processing salary payments once a month is an example of a batch workload.
Correct.
Salary payments processed once a month involve gathering data over time (e.g., payroll information) and processing it in bulk at a specific interval, which is a classic example of a batch workload.

A wind turbine that sends 50 sensor readings per second is an example of a streaming workload.
Correct.
Continuous sensor readings from a wind turbine at 50 readings per second represent a streaming workload, where data is processed in real time as it arrives.

A home electricity meter that sends readings once a day to an energy provider is an example of a streaming workload.
Incorrect.
Sending electricity meter readings once a day is not a streaming workload because data is collected and sent in bulk at a scheduled interval (daily). This is more of a batch workload.

discussion.content:
Y, Y, N.
Streaming is synonymous with low latency (usually fractions of a second). 24 hour interval/latency does not constitute streaming in this scenario.
y,y,n is correct

the device sends the readings --> so it is IOT Hub streaming. I believe if they mentioned, job reads the readings from devices over night, it would mean a batch process is triggered to read ALL devices. but here our streaming job is running and waiting any devices to send the data.
I think the answer should be Yes, yes, No. The option B says "50 sensor readings per second"
The third is not real time process, so it is not streaming process.
Agree, Yes, Yes, No!
yes yes no

Read the sentences carefully. They give different solutions architecture scenarios. Where capturing data from devices and batch the information once per day is one thing, another is to stream data in real time to be processed. The electric meter is a typical example of batch. The sensors as being critical in real time is streaming (if something fails you need to provision a solution in real time). The payments one is a typical example of processing in batch by querying a big amount of information. I agree with the responses.
In my opinions... "it sends readingS". Plural means multiple values. So imho the answer is correct.
When buffering is involved its batch processing. Should be yes yes no

comments.content: There is no buffering in electricity metrics. The data is sent once a day with no processing at all. It is a real time information at the time the device sends it.
And if the readings are sent once per week, or per month? No, the readings are sent IN BATCHES, so it's not real time.

discussion.content: yes, yes, no.

I think the answer should be Yes, Yes, Yes. The option C is talking about a device that sends data once a day but it is the frequency in which that device works, it is not accumulating data and then sending it. When the data is received it should be processed in real time.

comments.content: Streaming assume that you can do aggregates and simple operations, commonly in time windows, 1 update per day doesn't allow you to keep enough data in memory to do some statistics. Probably a likewise scenario is more to store daily recaps than reacting near real-time to events.

discussion.content: Yes,Yes,Yes. An electric meter is an IOT device, with an interval of 1 day. It is real time data from the device and can flow from an IOT Hub to Azure in real time as a stream

comments.content: It is when you have several hundred thousand meters sending once per day.
near real time only means available at target immediately when produced, not related to frequency.
Stream data is near real time, 1 day frequency is not near real time.

comments.content:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/modules/explore-fundamentals-stream-processing/2-batch-stream
yny is correct. What other documentation did you use to get ynn

discussion.content: y,n,y is correct

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/modules/explore-fundamentals-stream-processing/2-batch-stream
Analysis: You typically use batch processing to perform complex analytics. Stream processing is used for simple response functions, aggregates, or calculations such as rolling averages.

Yes - Stream processing has access to the most recent data received or data within a rolling time window. Stream processing operates on data in near real-time, allowing for analysis and processing of data as it is received or within a defined time window.

No - Batch processing is not required to occur immediately and can have higher latency. Batch processing typically operates on larger volumes of data and is often performed at regular intervals or in scheduled batches, which can have latency in the order of minutes, hours, or even days.

Yes - Stream processing is commonly used for simple response functions, aggregates, or calculations such as rolling averages. It enables real-time data analysis and enables quick calculations and aggregations on streaming data as it arrives.

comments.content: stream processing is often used for simple response functions, aggregates, or calculations such as rolling averages. Stream processing is a type of data processing that allows you to analyze, process and act on data as it is generated or received, in real-time. This type of processing is well-suited for use cases such as monitoring sensor data, analyzing log files, and running real-time analytics on financial or telemetry data, therefore it can be used to perform simple calculations like aggregates or rolling averages. Additionally, it also allows to perform complex calculations and machine learning models in near real-time.

questions.question_text:
You need to perform hybrid transactional and analytical processing (HTAP) queries against Azure Cosmos DB data sources by using Azure Synapse Analytics.
What should you use?

discussion.content: Exam 26/09.. C is correct

Synapse Link is a feature of Azure Cosmos DB that allows you to enable real-time analytics on your Cosmos DB data, by creating a seamless connection between Azure Cosmos DB and Azure Synapse Analytics. It enables you to run analytical queries against your Cosmos DB data using Synapse SQL pool, and perform complex joins and aggregations across data stored in both Cosmos DB and other data sources.

Hybrid Transactional and Analytical Processing (HTAP) is a technique for near real time analytics without a complex ETL solution. In Azure Synapse Analytics, HTAP is supported through Azure Synapse Link.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/training/paths/work-with-hybrid-transactional-analytical-processing-solutions/#:~:text=Hybrid%20Transactional%20and%20Analytical%20Processing%20(HTAP)%20is%20a%20technique%20for,Data%20Engineering%20on%20Microsoft%20Azure.
